parts.text: Write a LinkedIn post where you discuss the benefits you've experienced after achieving 10 million impressions on the platform in the last 14 days, including the impact on your startup and personal brand. Also, encourage other founders or people to use the platform for their growth. End the post by promising to share your LinkedIn growth strategies if the post receives 1,000 likes.

I got 10 million impressions on LinkedIn in the last 14 days…

This has helped me:

- Drive thousands of users to my startup
- Set new records for user and revenue growth (+30%)
- Grow my personal brand
- Take photos with Simplify users at the club

I say this to encourage other founders / people to post here – it’s literally free game to grow your brand or company.

You can overcome the cringe (or just become it).

P.S. If this post gets 1,000 likes I’ll share my playbook for LinkedIn Growth in another post!
As the CEO of Simplify, write a humorous LinkedIn post about how you reduced your iPhone screen time.

As a founder, I recently lowered my iPhone screen time by over 5 hours/day. 

Here’s the #1 trick that helped me do it:


*

I bought a new iPad and began using it for 5 extra hours a day instead. 

Turns out, the easiest way to reduce screen time is to transfer that time to another device…

P.S. If you ACTUALLY want to know how I optimize my time as the CEO of Simplify, leave a comment!

Write a LinkedIn post where you share your experience of being laid off recently, how it led you to finding the job portal Simplify, how it has helped you save time and effort, and make a shoutout to its creators. Also, briefly advertise your skills and expertise as a Data Scientist open for opportunities. Use relevant hashtags at the end.

Job hunting sucks. 😩 Simplify made it suck way less. 🚀
Got laid off recently — not the best feeling. And if you’ve ever been in the job search grind, you know how draining it is. Some portals (👀 you, Workday) legit take 30+ mins just to apply to one role. Wild.
Then I found Simplify— and wow.
 ⚡️ One-click applications
 ⚡️ Smart matching
 ⚡️ Saved me HOURS of soul-crushing form-filling
Built by just a 6-person team — and it’s helped me more than most big-name tools ever have. 🙌
 Shoutout to Michael Yan and team for creating something that gives people real hope.
If you’re job hunting — go check it out: https://simplify.jobs
Oh — and if you're looking for a Data Scientist who knows way more than just prompt engineering (think: real ML, causal inference, production-ready stuff) — hit me up. DMs open. 📩
#JobSearch #SimplifyJobs #LaidOffLife #DataScience #CareerGlowUp #StartupLove #MoreThanPromptEngineering
Write a blog post about your personal experience with writing cover letters in college and why you decided to create an AI Cover Letter Generator at your company, Simplify.

I wasted over 100 hours writing cover letters in college.

I hated writing them, they didn’t always get read, and they always took up a disproportionate amount of time during my job search. 

⚡️That’s why we created an AI Cover Letter Generator at Simplify!  

It's simple: Input your preferences, and it creates a personalized cover letter that showcases your skills based on your resume and the job description.

1 hour → 10 seconds. 

So if you are a sucky writer (like I am) check it out!

Compose a detailed announcement for the launch of a gap year program called "Garden Fellowship" aimed at exceptional undergraduate computer science and pre-law students, providing them an opportunity to gain practical experience. The announcement should include the benefits, requirements, working conditions, and contact information.

Garden Fellowship: Gap Year Internship for Talented Undergrads

We’re launching a gap year program for exceptional undergraduate computer science and pre-law students.

When I took a year off in college to work at Gemini (startup) and Matrix (hedge fund), I gained invaluable insights that I couldn’t have gotten in the classroom. It was one of the best decisions I ever made. However, this path wouldn’t have been possible without a generous scholarship from the Bryan Cameron Education Foundation.

Now, I want to offer this opportunity to you.

How It Works:

> Summer 2025 internship at Garden
> Option to extend to a full year (by taking a leave of absence)
> Paid full-time salary: $7,000/month for legal backgrounds, $10,000/month for technical backgrounds
> $50,000 grant toward your tuition if you extend for a full year
> Must work in person in NYC

You Are:

> A current sophomore or junior at an accredited four-year university
> Passionate about startups and curious about the intersection of technology, law, and business
> A computer science student who loves to build, ships fast, and is a whiz at going 0 to 1 on web dev projects
OR 
> a pre-law student with a related major, interested in intellectual property law and emerging technology

We’re living through an AI research supercycle—this is an ideal time to learn, build, and grow.

We’re accepting 1–2 fellows over the next six months, with flexible start and end dates. You’ll need to hustle and be high-agency—but if you’re hungry to learn and want to be part of something ambitious, we’d love to hear from you.

Interested? Introduce yourself and send us your LinkedIn at fellowship@gardenintel.com

Write a humorous, self-deprecating post about how receiving a teddy bear from a user of your app, Simplify, changed your dating life on Hinge. Be sure to end the post by asking for teddy bear name suggestions and encouraging more people to sign up for Simplify.

I recently got a gift from a Simplify user…

A teddy bear.

He saw my posts about being single (and chronically on Hinge) – and decided to send me a bear "for my future girlfriend."

Not gonna lie… I laughed. But then I actually added the bear to my Hinge profile.

Update: It worked. I’ve finally started getting real matches, instead of just people asking me for jobs....

P.S. I’m taking name suggestions – drop them below 👇

P.P.S. If you really want to send me a gift, sign up for Simplify 😉

Share a useful hack or trick you discovered that helped you land job offers at top tech companies like Meta and Google. Also, explain how it works and credit the original source of the hack if applicable.

I landed job offers at Meta & Google because I applied to the jobs within a few hours of them being posted. 

Here's the LinkedIn hack I used that makes finding newly-posted jobs way easier: 

I used to spend 2-3 hours a day refreshing job boards to find jobs as soon as they were posted. 

I knew that applying for jobs quickly would increase my chances of landing an interview, but it was SO inefficient looking through hundreds of jobs to find the most recently posted ones. 

Luckily, I found a way on LinkedIn to only filter for jobs that have been posted within the past HOUR. Here’s how it works: 

1. Search for your desired job and filter for “Past 24 hours” 
2. In the URL, change "86400" to "3600"
3. Browse all the jobs that have been posted within 1 hour!

💡 How does this work? 

The “86400” number stands for the amount of seconds it has been since a job has been posted. 

86400 = 24 hours, and 3600 = 1 hour. 

Meaning, by changing the URL you will only be shown jobs that have been posted in the past 1 hour. You can also play around with the number to filter for jobs that have been posted within any amount of time. 

Shoutout to run_amucks on reddit for sharing this :)

𝗣.𝗦. You’ll still need to fill out the job application once you find it… here’s a free extension that autofills your job applications (including those pesky Workday ones): https://lnkd.in/gp4dCNZV

Write a social media post reflecting on your journey from presenting at Y Combinator's Demo Day four years ago to successfully growing your job application autofill platform, Simplify, highlighting key milestones and expressing gratitude to your users and investors.

Four years ago, I pitched at Y Combinator's Demo Day–on my birthday.

I had just dropped out of Stanford and had been working 80 hours/week on my job application autofill Chrome Extension. 

My parents wanted me to finish my degree, and I felt a ton of pressure to "figure things out"  

At the time, my only birthday wish was to successfully demo our product in front of the ~1,500 investors who showed up to Demo Day (which we thankfully did). 

Fast forward to today, and it's CRAZY to see how far Simplify has come...

1,500 users → ~1 million users 
1 feature → 10+ features 
Chrome Extension → Full-spectrum job search platform
$0 revenue → $X,000,000 revenue

Shoutout to the best users in the world (& investors!) for believing in us 🥳

P.S. I don't look like this anymore, please don't cyberbully me.
As a developer of a Chrome extension that assists with job applications, write a LinkedIn post reacting to a former teacher who now uses and commends your product.

Glad he enjoys my product more than I enjoyed his class….

PSA: the Chrome extension he's talking about helps you autofill job applications (yes, including the Workday ones): https://lnkd.in/gDu9UTvy

Write a LinkedIn post explaining a simple algorithm hack that helped you land interviews at top tier companies like Stripe, Citadel, and Bridgewater. In the post, include a step-by-step guide on how others can use this hack in their job search.

I landed interviews at Stripe, Citadel, and Bridgewater because I used this LinkedIn algorithm hack…

Here's the trick that got me 10+ inbound recruiter messages that most people never take advantage of: 

When I was in college, I didn’t have a fancy resume or a big-name internship.

But recruiters from top tier companies still reached out to me—completely unprompted.

So what was the hack?

💡 I asked my friends and coworkers to endorse my LinkedIn skills.

Here’s why that matters:

When a recruiter searches for something like “Python” or “Data Analysis,” LinkedIn doesn’t just show every profile that lists the skill…

It prioritizes profiles based on how many endorsements each skill has.

Let’s say you and I both list “Python.”
If I have 15 endorsements and you have 0—I rank higher.

That tiny tweak boosted my visibility—and suddenly, recruiters were finding ME.

If you’re job hunting right now, here’s how you can use this LinkedIn algorithm hack:

1.	Pick 5–10 skills that are relevant to the jobs you want
2.	Add them to your profile (under the “Skills” section)
3.	Ask your friends, classmates, coworkers to endorse you

This takes 5 minutes—but the upside is HUGE.

It’s one of the most underrated ways to land interviews without even applying.

P.S. If you’re not sure which skills to add, Simplify has a free keyword tool that suggests keywords to use based on job descriptions: https://lnkd.in/gG-zUVAa

Write a humorous April Fools post from the perspective of the CEO of a successful job application startup, announcing that the company has been bought by Workday, one of the biggest names in HR software.

🎉 Huge news: Workday is acquiring Simplify.

When I dropped out of Stanford in 2021 to build Simplify, all I wanted was to make applying to jobs easier.

Four years later, we’ve grown to over 1 million users and helped them apply to over 100 million jobs — including more than 10 million on Workday alone.

It truly feels full circle to share that we’ll be joining one of the biggest names in recruiting tech.

Workday is one of the largest players in HR software, and they’ve always prioritized the candidate experience.

We’re genuinely excited to work together to make job searching better for everyone.

Huge thank you to our team, our users, and our investors – Y Combinator, Craft Ventures, and our NEWEST BACKER #AprilFools VC – for believing in our team and our mission.

We’re just getting started 🚀🚀🚀

(Yes… this is an April Fools joke. We’re still independent 😄)

So, if you hate manually filling out job applications, check out Simplify here: https://lnkd.in/gTtMvmDK
Write a promotional post for a new job-search dashboard feature from the perspective of a user who was struggling with their job search before using the new feature.

After applying to my first 50 jobs in college, I felt super burnt-out…

I landed 0 interviews and thought about giving up completely. 

The worst part wasn't the rejections—it was being unsure if my effort was leading somewhere. I had a hard time tracking my progress and felt like I was aimlessly applying to jobs. 

🥳 That’s why we launched a our new dashboard to help you stay on track with in your job search!

You’ll now be able to: 
• Easily view hundreds of relevant job matches 
• Set weekly job-search goals  
• View your stats (applications, interviews, & saved-jobs)
• See how many hours you’ve saved by using our extension ;)  

Plus, if you hit a 7 day streak we’ll feature your profile to the recruiters on our platform to help you land more interviews!

👉Use it now: https://lnkd.in/gw4_s-vY

Share a story about an unusual experience you had with a job-seeker trying to network with you through an unconventional platform, such as a dating app. Ask your audience if they think you should give this person a job interview. Also, mention the overwhelming response you've received from job-seekers after sharing a similar story previously.

Last week, I posted about a job-seeker trying to network with me on Hinge….

Today, she reached out on LinkedIn confessing it was her.

Comment below: Should I give her a job interview? 

P.S. Also yes, those 3,401 Hinge notifications are real… I’ve had my inbox flooded by job-seekers since posting last week 💀

Write a cautionary post about a recent incident where you, as a leader of the Simplify team, were impersonated and someone tried to scam your Campus Ambassadors. Include a PSA about what you would never ask your team to do and a reminder to verify any suspicious messages.

I recently got impersonated…..

A few days ago, one of the Simplify Campus Ambassadors (Abbasali) got a message from someone pretending to be me: 

The impersonator asked them to buy Apple Gift cards. 

Fortunately, our ambassadors are too smart for that.

PSA: There are 2 things I will NEVER ask you to do – send me an Apple Gift card OR manually fill out a Workday application…

𝗜𝗻 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝘀𝗲𝗿𝗶𝗼𝘂𝘀𝗻𝗲𝘀𝘀, 𝗽𝗹𝗲𝗮𝘀𝗲 𝗯𝗲 𝗰𝗮𝗿𝗲𝗳𝘂𝗹!!! If you are ever unsure if a message is real, please check with the Simplify team through our support email!!!

Write a blog post from the perspective of a college graduate who has applied to numerous internships, detailing their experience with different application platforms and announcing a new "Simple Applications" feature on their job search website, Simplify.

When I applied to over 150 internships in college, I noticed one thing: 

Certain job applications took WAY longer to fill out than others (*cough* Workday)

While some applications only took 1-2 minutes to fill out, others took 15-20+ minutes. 

The shorter applications just asked for my resume, while the long ones forced me to retype my experience, enter skills manually, and make a new account for each job… 

I thought this was crazy, and I realized focusing on easier job applications saved me a TON of time and allowed me to apply to more jobs.

🎊 That’s why I’m excited to announce: You can now directly toggle for “Simple Applications” on Simplify!

When you turn this filter on, you’ll only see a list of jobs that are basic and straightforward to fill out (aka, no workday…)

We’re hoping this feature will help job-seekers apply to more positions faster, without the headache of long, complicated application portals.

Write a social media post about a unique life hack to increase productivity, and include a call to action for audience engagement.

Life hack to 10x your productivity:


Record a timelapse of yourself while working.

It's like having a virtual accountability partner watching over your shoulder.

Plus, it's oddly satisfying to watch yourself be productive in 10x speed.

P.S. If this post gets 1000 likes, I’ll post a Simplify team vlog!

Write a reflective birthday post on your journey from a 20-year-old college dropout to the CEO of a successful startup, Simplify, that has helped almost a million people find jobs. Include your experience of being a part of Y Combinator and how you've grown and learnt over the years. End with a humorous note about still looking young and a plug for your company.

Today’s my birthday. 

Four years ago, I was 20 and had just dropped out of Stanford.

I was living in a tiny Airbnb in Mountain View and trying to convince myself (and my Asian parents) that starting a company wasn’t a terrible idea.

I had just gotten into Y Combinator, was basically broke, and had a product that barely worked.

Today, Simplify has helped nearly a million people apply to 80 million jobs. Crazy.

If there’s one thing I’ve learned over the years, it’s this: you don’t need to have it all figured out to get started. At 20, I definitely didn’t. Honestly, I still don’t.

Here’s to another year of figuring things out.

P.S. Yes, this photo is from back when we were just kids going through YC. No, I have not aged a single day since. Yes, I still get ID’d.

P.P.S. If your birthday wish is to get hired, check out Simplify :)

Write a personal story about how you identified a problem during your college days, came up with a solution, developed a startup around it, and how it has grown to the present day. Include some humorous elements and a call to action at the end.

I built the prototype for my startup in my dorm room.

As a sophomore at Stanford, I spent over 100 hours applying to jobs. 

I hated it.

I'd job search during my free time, on the weekends, and even during class instead of paying attention to lectures. 

To be honest, I hated manually finding and filling out job applications – I just assumed that’s how recruiting worked.

💡 But then I had an idea: a job application autofiller. 

As a CS major with some side-project experience, I wrote a basic script that auto-typed redundant information on my job applications. 

I realized it saved me a LOT of time – nearly 10 minutes per application.

I started sharing it around nearby colleges myself (I even handed out over 20,000 Squid Game themed business cards to promote it). After a few weeks, I remember hitting our first 1,000 users. 

Cliche, but it was crazy. 

🎉 Today, Simplify has helped nearly a million job seekers apply to 80 million jobs, and we’re a 7-person team shipping new features every single week.  

The lesson? You can just do things.

P.S. Before you comment about my messy room, just know this was BEFORE I had a girlfriend….

P.P.S. If you're looking for a job and re-typing your resume on job boards, check out Simplify: https://lnkd.in/gd74n6Xq

When I was a kid, my parents (like most other Asian parents) wanted me to go to Harvard.

Sadly, the admissions board said the feeling wasn’t mutual - which turned out great because my high school ex ended up going there….

All that aside, I'm super excited to announce: Simplify was featured as one of the top job-search resources used by students at Harvard!

Check out Simplify here: https://lnkd.in/gMFtbiFZ
And the PittCSC Repo here: https://lnkd.in/gCvwy32H

Write a LinkedIn post as the CEO of a job search platform called "Simplify", sharing an inspiring story about a user who found a job through your platform despite her high qualifications and struggles in the job market. Make sure to emphasize the challenges of modern job searching and how your platform aims to address those issues.

I just got a CRAZY message on LinkedIn:

A job-seeker messaged me saying that our platform helped her find a job and keep her house. But here’s where it gets crazier...

She has:
• A Master’s Degree 
• 17 years of experience (with experience at Apple & Meta)
• The ability to speak 4 languages

Regardless of her qualifications, she still struggled to find a job. 

As ridiculous as it is, finding a job today isn’t even about having the right experience anymore. It’s about being able to navigate the frustrating complexity of job-searching, and that's what we're trying to solve at Simplify.

Thank you for sharing your story Teresa :)

And if you're actively job searching, make sure to give Simplify a shot: https://lnkd.in/gZkcDNy7

Write a celebratory announcement for a jobs platform, Simplify, that is expanding its services from the U.S, Canada, and U.K to include Ireland, Australia, Germany, and France. The announcement should include a reference to St. Patrick’s Day for the expansion to Ireland and encourage readers to browse the new job listings. Also, it should hint at further expansion later in the year and ask for suggestions on where to expand next.

🍀 Announcement: Simplify is expanding globally! 

When we launched our jobs platform a few years ago, we wanted to make it available for everyone around the world.  

And yet for the past couple of years, we’ve only offered roles from the U.S, Canada, and U.K.  

Today… that changes. 

🎉 We’re now officially listing jobs in Ireland (Happy St. Patrick’s Day! 🍀), Australia, Germany, and France! 

You can now filter and find thousands of roles in these countries, with more being added every single day. 

It's a huge step for us and anyone looking for a job in these countries.

👉 Go browse our new roles now: https://lnkd.in/g84EKA4T

P.S. We’re hoping to expand to more countries later this year – comment below letting us know where you’d like to see Simplify next! 👀

Write a promotional post for a newly launched AI job application tracker tool that was developed based on personal experiences with job hunting.

🎁 Introducing: our new AI job application tracker! 

I applied for 200+ internships throughout college, and wasted a ton of time tracking them in a spreadsheet. 

I’d spend hours manually updating statuses, copy-pasting job descriptions, and trying to remember which version of my resume I used.

To fix this, we just launched our new job tracker that tracks all your applications in one place. 

It's everything I wish I had back then:
• Automatically adds your applications
• Saves job descriptions & resumes/cover letters
• Status columns (applied, interviewed, offered, etc.)
• Notes for your interviews

🎊 Plus, we’ll give you a fun confetti animation when you move a job to the “Offer” column :) 

👉 Use it now: https://lnkd.in/gvaZc3vQ

Write a post about the top 3 AI tools that can help in job hunting, including how they can be used and why you recommend them. Also, mention a bonus tool and provide an offer for a free subscription to your suite of AI job search tools.

When I was looking for my first job, I had ZERO access to AI tools for job hunting. 

Fast forward 5 years, and there are so many great ones. Here are my 3 favorite AI tools you need to use if you want to land a job right now: 

1. Perplexity: 

I’ve lost track of how many times I’ve recommended this AI search engine. My favorite use-cases are: 
• Doing company research for interviews 
• Figuring out recent hiring trends 
• Finding salary info 
 
2. ChatGPT (w/Voice) 

ChatGPT’s recent “Voice” feature lets you speak with it out loud, making mock interviews feel significantly more real. It also makes for a great therapist 😭

📌 Follow this prompt to do one: 

“I’m a [professional status] interviewing for [role] at [company]. Pretend you’re a recruiter at this company, and conduct a [type of interview]. Provide me in-depth feedback at the end after I say the keywords “end interview”.”

3. GranolaAI: 

I use this AI note-taker for all my personal meetings. 

Taking notes during coffee chats / informational interviews takes away from the actual conversation, so using a notetaker like this will save a ton of time. Highly recommend. Here's a link: https://lnkd.in/gf-RpMtD


Bonus: Simplify
Browse non-scammy jobs, autofill your applications, generate AI resumes and cover letters, track your applications. A no-brainer.

*P.S. Want a free $90 subscription to our suite of AI job search tools? 

Comment “Simplify” below, and I’ll pick a random winner!

Write a social media post from the perspective of the CEO of Simplify, sharing about a recent visit to the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, where they met with campus ambassadors and hosted a Q&A session. The CEO should mention some of the topics covered, the experience of meeting the students, and specific individuals who helped host the event. The post should also express the hope to return in the future.

Proud to share that one in five students at the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign is a user of Simplify!

This weekend, I flew out to Champaign to meet with our campus ambassadors and host a Q&A for the over 10,000 Simplify users at U of I. 

Some topics we covered: 
• Lessons from dropping out of college to build a startup 
• Building a personal brand in 2025
• Where Simplify is headed 

I met a ton of great students, and it was super cool seeing our impact on students first-hand (fun fact: UIUC is the 7th largest Simplify user base in the country!) 
 
A big shoutout to the 200+ students that came, and shoutout to Sachin Kumar and Cortez Ramos for the hosting! 

Hope to be back in the future 🫡

Write a social media post about the recent launch of the Campus Ambassador Program at your company, Simplify, and its success so far. Include a personal anecdote from the early days of the company, express gratitude to the ambassadors, and encourage others to join in the next semester.

For the past month, we’ve had 40+ ambassadors driving brand awareness around U.S. college campuses.

It's been super cool to see – I still remember when we first launched and would drive around to universities ourselves, personally asking people to sign up for our platform.  

Huge shoutout to the ambassadors for crushing it, and can’t wait to see what they come up with for the rest of the semester :) 

P.S. Want to bring Simplify to your college next semester? Leave a comment below with your school’s name!

Write a blog post about your experiences with resume templates on Canva and Microsoft Word, including the issues you encountered, why you think they're a problem, and how you eventually found a better solution.

I 𝗵𝗮𝘁𝗲 the resume templates on Canva and Microsoft Word

When I was in college and applying for my first internship, I tried using the templates on these sites and got ZERO interviews. 

That's when I learned a hard truth: These popular resume templates are actually terrible for job seekers. 

This is because: 
1. They're not optimized for the ATS (Applicant Tracking Systems).
2. Their fancy designs and colors make them hard to read.
3. Recruiters just don't like them.

It was only when I switched to a cleaner template I got from the Stanford Career Center that I started landing interviews (& jobs from companies like Meta, Microsoft, and more!) 

End of the day, a resume's job is to get the information across in a consistent and clear way. That’s it. 

As much as I love products like Canva and Word, it's shocking that they haven’t added useful resume templates from a job-hunting perspective.

If you want the template I received from Stanford, check it out here (it's the same as the famous "Jake's Resume"): https://lnkd.in/gXQuzd93

Write a guide on how to effectively use LinkedIn to land job offers at top tech companies like Meta, Microsoft, and Google by finding hiring managers and sending them thoughtful messages. Include a pro tip and a helpful resource to make the job application process easier.

I landed offers at Meta, Microsoft, and Google because I took advantage of this LinkedIn hack….

This is the easiest way to find 100+ hiring managers on LinkedIn whose inboxes aren’t filled with thousands of other people. 

Here’s how it works: 

Go to the search bar and type "hiring [ideal job title]" (e.g. "hiring software engineer"). 

✅ Make sure to include the quotes.

Then filter for "posts" and sort by "latest". 

This will show you a long list of people actively hiring for the job you want.

What’s crazy is that 90% of these hiring managers are getting less than 30 likes on their “hiring” posts–meaning they aren’t getting bombarded by people asking for referrals and interviews.

*Pro tip: Send the hiring manager a 𝘁𝗵𝗼𝘂𝗴𝗵𝘁𝗳𝘂𝗹𝗹𝘆 crafted cold message explaining why you’re a good fit–you’d be surprised by how many people respond! 

P.S. You'll probably still have to apply to the role – here's a free extension that autofills your job applications. Go to https://lnkd.in/gpcbAXCS

Write a reflective post about your journey as a founder of a start-up company, from your early days as a student at Stanford to the present day where your company, Simplify, has helped hundreds of thousands of people apply for jobs. Include your thoughts on the progress made and your ambition for the future.

Four years ago, I walked into an apartment in this exact building for the first time.

I was a 20-year-old Stanford student on financial aid, heading into one of my first investor meetings.

At the time, we had helped ~5,000 job seekers apply to around 100,000 jobs.

It was just me and my two co-founders, trying to build something from nothing.

I remember looking out at the view and thinking:
“We have a long way to go....”

Now, four years later Simplify has helped 800,000+ users apply to 70M+ jobs, leading to tens of thousands of offers.

I've also gotten the privilege of moving into this apartment building – which has temporarily turned into Simplify HQ while we wait for our new office 🤩

A lot has changed.
But there’s still so much more to build!

Write a personal story about the challenges faced by your father while searching for a job in the U.S. when you were born. Use this story to explain why you are building "Simplify", a tool to make job searching accessible for everyone. Also, include a real-world example of someone named Michelle who faced similar challenges, and provide a link to your product at the end of the story.

When I was born, my Dad had just moved to the U.S. and was looking for a job. 

Like clockwork, he would apply for jobs every day using Monster and Indeed. 

It took him 50+ applications to land his first job. 

The process was so time-consuming he would spend up to 30 minutes just to find and apply for one job. 

Two decades later, little has changed.

When Michelle sent me this email, it again reminded me of why I’m building Simplify. 

The mission is simple: to make job searching accessible for everyone. 

Whether you’re like my Dad and Michelle and taking care of a child or just a busy person, we all deserve to be able to apply for jobs on a level playing field.

Check out Simplify here: https://lnkd.in/geJ_RZtu

Write a LinkedIn post reflecting on your experience of submitting your first full-time job application as a soon-to-be college graduate in May 2025. Share your thoughts, feelings, strategies, and the support you've received. Don't forget to mention your goal of submitting one application a day, your method of tracking your applications, and the role of networking and resources such as Simplify in your job search.

I submitted my first full-time job application today! (Yay!)

Like many of my peers in the May 2025 college graduate cohort, I'm officially starting what will no doubt be a months-long search to secure a full-time position after graduating with my Bachelor's degree in May.

I'll admit, it's extremely daunting knowing the journey that's ahead. I know I'll repeatedly experience feelings of self-doubt and imposter syndrome. However, I know I’m not alone in navigating a challenging job market, especially in competitive fields like tech, finance, and project management.

So, why is my first post since 2023 about submitting my first full-time job application? Well, on top of fulfilling a personal goal of being more proactive with my overall health (mentally, socially, and physically), I wanted to take the first step by actually starting. By embracing an optimistic mindset, I can stay focused and motivated while overcoming feelings of burnout and discouragement.

I've set a goal for myself to submit one application every day. One application a day, each with a tailored resume and cover letter. I make sure to thoroughly research the role beforehand, ensuring it’s a good fit. And, of course, I make sure to keep track using a spreadsheet. :)

I'm extremely grateful for the support and guidance I've received thus far from my connections, friends, professors, and even my fellow LinkedIn peers. Reading about or hearing your stories helps keep me grounded, reminding me that there is no one-size-fits-all approach to finding fulfillment in any field or interest.

Wishing the best to all of us looking for our next opportunities. I'm excited to see what doors will be open to you in 2025!

---------
Inspired by Angela Richard, M.Ed.'s post, who provided some tips on how to remain focused and positive during the process.

Additional thanks to Michael Yan and the team at Simplify. It's incredible seeing Simplify's growth since I first discovered the platform in 2023 via Instagram. I cannot emphasize enough how invaluable this resource has been for every single role I've applied to and later accepted. You guys are seriously the best, and I can't wait to see where you go from here!

Share a personal story about successfully cold emailing a popular YouTuber and provide tips on how to craft an effective cold email.

Here's how I cold emailed a YouTuber with 2 million subs– and got a response.

I’ve been watching Jomatech for the last 7 years (since I was in high school). 

When Simplify wanted to launch an influencer marketing campaign, I cold-emailed him and got a response. 

Cold emails are super underrated – one of the easiest ways to meet people and land a job (this is also how got my Meta internship years ago).  

Luckily, I’ve tried 100+ iterations of cold emails which taught me how to get responses. 

Here are 3 takeaways from this email I sent: 👇

𝟭.  𝗥𝗲𝗹𝗮𝘁𝗲 𝘁𝗼 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗱𝗲𝗿: 
I talked about how watching Joma’s content inspired me to major in CS and go into Tech, and brought up an inside joke from his channel about going to Stanford.

While I didn’t know him personally, this provided common ground for us to relate.

𝟮. 𝗜𝗻𝗰𝗹𝘂𝗱𝗲 𝘀𝗼𝗰𝗶𝗮𝗹 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗼𝗳: 
In my email, I referenced having thousands of users, being featured on CNN, and our list of investors. 

If you’re looking for a job, you can talk about major work experiences, projects you’ve worked on, or anything else that sets you apart from everyone else. 

𝟯. 𝗨𝘀𝗲 𝗮 𝗧𝗟𝗗𝗥 𝗮𝘁 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗯𝗲𝗴𝗶𝗻𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴: 
TLDR stands for “Too Long, Didn’t Read”. 

It’s a way to put your value prop at the beginning of your message, so the reader understands your email in one line. 

This saves time and ups your chances of getting a response like crazy. 

Cold messages have helped me in every area of my life: growing Simplify, landing jobs, dating (IG DMs are an art) – highly recommend them.

Write a blog post about your experience of turning your living room into a temporary office for your startup team. Include the benefits, challenges, and the importance of in-person work. Also, give a hint about your future permanent workspace.

I turned my living room into our startup office this week.

Our team is in the middle of transitioning offices in SF. Instead of working remotely, we decided to bring the office to my apartment.

It's a unique experience, to say the least. 

Waking up and walking straight into our "office" has its perks:

✅ Zero commute.
✅ Snack bar is now my kitchen. 
✅ Team meetings are on my couch. 

It's a bit chaotic, but also super fun. 

But it's more than just convenience. 

There's something about in-person work that remote just can't replicate. (We had an uncrustable eating contest)

For example, one of my engineers keeps a framed YC rejection letter on his desk that we get to see every day. 

It’s a bit cliche, but seeing that on his desk is a constant reminder of what we’re trying to prove. 

In the grand scheme of things, I’m a big believer that these little things add up.

In-person > Remote. 

P.S. For those wondering about our permanent workspace... stay tuned. 

Our new San Francisco HQ is coming soon, and it's going to be worth the wait :)

Write an analysis on how Duolingo capitalized on the temporary TikTok ban to increase their app usage, with specific emphasis on their strategic use of social media.

I just saw Duolingo dominate on social media because of the TikTok ban. 

Here's how they used the ban to drive a 216% increase on their app: 

Over the past 24 hours, TikTok has gone from being inaccessible in the U.S. to being fully back online and functional. 

But here's the thing: 

When American users realized they might be unable to access TikTok, they started looking for alternatives. 

As a result, over 3 million U.S. users joined the Chinese social media app called Rednote. 

While Duolingo isn't inherently tied to Rednote, they realized the shift into a Mandarin-based social media would create an influx of consumers wanting to learn the language. 

This is how they capitalized on it:

✅ They began creating content specifically around helping users learn Mandarin.

✅ On social media, they put out a very well-timed tweet saying "𝗼𝗵 𝘀𝗼 𝗡𝗢𝗪 𝘆𝗼𝘂’𝗿𝗲 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗺𝗮𝗻𝗱𝗮𝗿𝗶𝗻" that garnered over 16 million views.

✅ They put out multiple other viral tweets with links to learn Mandarin. 

I'm always impressed by how fast brands can move on social media, and this is nothing short of an amazing example. 

Special kudos to Kelsey Dempsey from the Duolingo team on understanding social timing and being able to capitalize on it. 

* 

P.S. I love paying attention to companies and how they operate. 

If you want more content like this, follow me Timothy for more.

👇 Here’s a bit about our resident (almost pro) golfer: 

𝗤𝘂𝗲𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻: "What inspired you to apply for this internship?" 

𝗥𝘆𝗮𝗻: When I was job hunting, I realized how frustrating and manual the application process is. I even tried to create a product to fix it, and that’s when I heard Michael on a YouTube video talking about Simplify. 

𝗤𝘂𝗲𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻: “What’s been your favorite part of working here so far?

𝗥𝘆𝗮𝗻: I love the close-knit team dynamic and how involved everyone is. I can bring an idea to the CEO, and within a couple of days, we’re able to turn it into something live for the public. 

𝗤𝘂𝗲𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻: “What’s a fun fact people would never know about you?” 

𝗥𝘆𝗮𝗻: I’ve been playing golf since I was 2, competed at the D1 college level, and almost turned pro after graduating.

𝗤𝘂𝗲𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻: “What’s your best piece of advice for someone looking for a job?” 

𝗥𝘆𝗮𝗻: Network hard and network early. It’s less about getting the referral to get that first interview and more about building relationships with people a couple of steps ahead of you.

I’m joining Simplify (Y Combinator W21) as a Software Engineering Intern!!

Why this is such a full circle moment for me:

When I was a freshman recruiting for my first internship, I hated the application process. Manually inputting all of my resume details (even after uploading it) got so exhausting. 

Especially when applying to 100+ positions in a tough job market.

The following summer, everything changed when I discovered Simplify. Their autofill tool slashed application time from 10 mins to less than 2. It 5xed my reach, helping me secure internships every summer. 

Two years later, I still use Simplify for all of my job apps and recommend it to all my friends. It has helped my friends and I work smarter in this rigorous job climate. 

Today, I'm proud to share that I am joining the team that has made all of this possible while I finish my final semester at Pitt!

Michael Yan and the team are reimagining how people find jobs, making the process more fair and accessible. I’m so grateful to now contribute to a mission that has meant so much to me!

Write a blog post reflecting on your experience of being invited to the "My First Million" podcast as a guest to participate in a pitch competition for your startup, Simplify. Include your feelings before, during, and after the event, and how this opportunity impacted your startup.

I’ve been a huge fan of the My First Million podcast for years – it’s one of the most popular business podcasts with millions of listeners.

When I first started Simplify, I never imagined I’d get the chance to share our story on the show.

So when I was invited on the podcast to compete in a pitch competition against other Stanford-founded startups, I was ecstatic.

It was an exciting opportunity to share what we’d been building and how Simplify is helping people navigate the (brutal) job search process.

Getting to show our product on a podcast I’ve admired for so long was surreal (and I even ended up winning the pitch competition!)

Huge thanks to the My First Million team for having me on!

I’ve been a huge fan of the My First Million podcast for years – it’s one of the most popular business podcasts with millions of listeners.

When I first started Simplify, I never imagined I’d get the chance to share our story on the show.

So when I was invited on the podcast to compete in a pitch competition against other Stanford-founded startups, I was ecstatic.

It was an exciting opportunity to share what we’d been building and how Simplify is helping people navigate the (brutal) job search process.

Getting to show our product on a podcast I’ve admired for so long was surreal (and I even ended up winning the pitch competition!)

Huge thanks to the My First Million team for having me on!

*I didn’t sleep much the night before, please excuse my appearance 💀

Write a motivational story about Elon Musk's journey with SpaceX, highlighting the challenges he faced, the risks he took, and the success he achieved. Use this story as a metaphor for overcoming adversity in our own careers.

Did you know that Elon Musk burned $100 million on failed rocket launches?
 
But his fourth attempt skyrocketed him to billionaire status.
 
This is a story of faith in the face of failure: 
 
In 2002, Elon Musk set out to make space travel affordable with SpaceX. 
 
Instead, he watched his first three rockets explode, burning through over $100 million—mostly his own money.
 
Critics scoffed. 
 
Investors fled. 
 
Facing bankruptcy, Musk had a choice: shut down or risk his last $40 million on one final launch.
 
On September 28, 2008, his fourth rocket soared successfully, making SpaceX the first private company to reach orbit. 
 
SpaceX is now worth 175 billion and has revolutionized the aerospace industry.
 
That launch didn't just save his company; it changed space travel.
 
In our careers, we all face "fourth launch" moments. 
 
Musk's journey reminds me: your biggest breakthroughs often come right after your most crushing failures.

Write a personal narrative about your father's job search struggles in the early 2000s, how it led you to drop out of Stanford and create a company called Simplify, and discuss the impact your company has made so far.

This is a photo of my dad, editing his resume and applying to his first job in 2001 – while holding 1-year old me.

In the early 2000s, my dad was editing his resume in Microsoft Word and power-used Indeed to find and apply to jobs. 

He spent over a year job searching, eventually taking a role only slightly related to his degree and skills. 

But the process was so frustrating that my dad has been at the same job ever since – 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗻𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗹𝘆 𝟮𝟱 𝘆𝗲𝗮𝗿𝘀.

Now, in 2024, 𝗶𝘁’𝘀 𝗰𝗿𝗮𝘇𝘆 𝗵𝗼𝘄 𝗹𝗶𝘁𝘁𝗹𝗲 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗰𝗲𝘀𝘀 𝗼𝗳 𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮 𝗷𝗼𝗯 𝗵𝗮𝘀 𝗰𝗵𝗮𝗻𝗴𝗲𝗱.

You still edit your resume in Word, find roles on job boards that have looked the same since 2000, and fill out (often) hundreds of applications. 

It’s still time-consuming, inefficient, and 𝗡𝗢𝗧 candidate-friendly.

It’s sad that the biggest change in these photos is me – and not the way hiring is done. 𝗕𝘂𝘁 𝘁𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝘀𝗵𝗼𝘂𝗹𝗱𝗻’𝘁 𝗯𝗲 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗰𝗮𝘀𝗲.

My dad's story is part of why I dropped out of Stanford to build Simplify – think of it as your 𝗽𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗼𝗻𝗮𝗹 𝗔𝗜-𝘁𝗮𝗹𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗮𝗴𝗲𝗻𝘁 that helps you 𝗼𝗿𝗴𝗮𝗻𝗶𝘇𝗲 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗳𝗲𝘀𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻𝗮𝗹 𝗷𝗼𝘂𝗿𝗻𝗲𝘆 and 𝗮𝗱𝘃𝗼𝗰𝗮𝘁𝗲 𝘁𝗼 𝗴𝗲𝘁 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗵𝗶𝗿𝗲𝗱.

Today, Simplify has helped over half a million candidates create over 1 million resumes and apply to over 40 million jobs.

We're on a mission to help 𝗘𝗩𝗘𝗥𝗬𝗢𝗡𝗘 find a job they truly love – in a way that doesn't make you want to pull your hair out.

Write a blog post as the founder of a job search platform called Simplify, sharing a success story of a first-generation college student named Jessica Lopez who, despite being born without hands and feet, was able to secure her first internship using Simplify. Highlight how the platform aims to make job searching accessible for everyone and invite users to share their stories.

When I sat down with Jessica Lopez, she told me about how she used Simplify to job search more efficiently and 𝗹𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗵𝗲𝗿 𝗙𝗜𝗥𝗦𝗧 𝗶𝗻𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗻𝘀𝗵𝗶𝗽. 

Jessica is a 𝗳𝗶𝗿𝘀𝘁-𝗴𝗲𝗻𝗲𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗰𝗼𝗹𝗹𝗲𝗴𝗲 𝘀𝘁𝘂𝗱𝗲𝗻𝘁 who was born without hands and feet.

After struggling to find the right jobs to apply for and manually fill out each repetitive application, Simplify helped level the playing field for her – allowing her to discover the right positions, apply to jobs in one-click, and at the end of the day, 𝗹𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗮 𝗷𝗼𝗯. 

That’s exactly 𝘄𝗵𝘆 we built this platform in the first place: 𝗧𝗼 𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗷𝗼𝗯 𝘀𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗰𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗺𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗮𝗰𝗰𝗲𝘀𝘀𝗶𝗯𝗹𝗲 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘆𝗼𝗻𝗲. 

Seeing Jessica's story (who also is a LinkedIn creator and an esteemed advocate for accessibility – follow her!) and our over 700K+ users has been the foundation for building Simplify. 

P.S. I love reading user stories!! If you have one you’d like to share, shoot me an email :)

Write a blog post detailing your experience with the job search tool "Simplify", how it helped you during your job hunt, and why you would recommend it to others.

Layoffs are happening. Every day, I see amazing talent in my network back on the market. Having recently been on the market myself, a tip:

Use Simplify. 

(They are not paying me to say this. I don't know them. It's just really good.)

Deep into my job hunt, I kept reading best practices that mentioned tailoring my resume to each job and writing a flawless cover letter. Great, in theory! But I had to choose between submitting 10 good applications a day and 3-4 great ones. In this market, and with the financial clock ticking, I had to choose the 10. Until I didn't.

-Simplify used AI to tailor my existing resume based on keywords found in each individual job posting. (Take that, arbitrary applicant-tracking systems!) 

-It helped me generate similarly keyword-rich cover letters that I could then personalize. (You don't have to, but 100% AI-generated content is painful, obvious, and painfully obvious.) 

-It also suggested job openings for me based on some extremely selective parameters. (I'm picky!)

Bonus: it cost 40 bucks for a 3-month subscription (the length of the average job search), and I got hired well before the subscription ended. The peace of mind alone was worth the cost, knowing that some fickle robot wouldn't reject me out of hand because I said "copywriting" instead of "copy writing". 

So, for all my friends newly on the job hunt, save yourself some time and elbow grease. Use something like Simplify, so you can play the numbers game without sacrificing quality.

Write a post as a social media manager sharing your experience and strategies in growing the Instagram followers of a job board company named Simplify from 0 to 51,000 in one year. Also, include a call-to-action for hiring a social media intern.

I grew Simplify’s Instagram from 𝟬 → 𝟱𝟭,𝟬𝟬𝟬 followers in 𝟭 𝘆𝗲𝗮𝗿. Here's how:

When we first started our Instagram in late 2022, we did NOT expect it to be a large driver of new users. 

I mean, who in their right mind wants to follow a job board?

We tailored our brand toward Gen Z job seekers by creating a combination of funny/relatable content and early-career recruiting advice.

It took around ~5 months of posting to figure out the style and type of content that resonated the most with our audience.

By mid-2023, we were running a consistent content calendar and had our first million-view video! 🤯

Today, our Reels have been viewed and shared over 10 million times. 🚀

𝗠𝗮𝗶𝗻 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴? You can make fun content regardless of the brand you are! (Shoutout to Ryanair - Europe's Favourite Airline 🫡)

-

P.S. We’re hiring for a social media intern to create content with us!

Share the story of how you met your co-founder and what led to the creation of your successful startup.

We became friends after unintentionally matching outfits and getting laughed at.

Later that year, we went through the brutal process of finding a job/internship. 

After 100s of applications, we decided to build a product to address some of the biggest challenges we faced in the job search (the prototype for Simplify!) 

One year later, Ethan and I both:  
• Dropped out of college (*the grad photo is fake, IYKYK)
• Turned down full-time job offers to do Y Combinator
• Moved to SF 

Today, we’ve built a platform that’s helped over half a million people apply to 40 million jobs. 

What I learned? Build companies with people who have a similar sense of fashion 🤠

As the founder of a successful job search platform, share your top 3 resume tips based on your experience in helping users apply to over 40 million jobs. Include details on the ATS-optimized resume template, keyword optimization based on job description, and the use of the XYZ format in resume bullet points.

I founded a job search platform that has helped users apply to over 𝟰𝟬 𝗺𝗶𝗹𝗹𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗷𝗼𝗯𝘀.

All those applications later, I wanted to share 𝟯 𝗼𝗳 𝗺𝘆 𝗯𝗲𝘀𝘁 𝗿𝗲𝘀𝘂𝗺𝗲 𝘁𝗶𝗽𝘀 for those actively job searching:

𝟭. 𝗨𝘀𝗲 𝗮𝗻 𝗔𝗧𝗦-𝗼𝗽𝘁𝗶𝗺𝗶𝘇𝗲𝗱 𝗿𝗲𝘀𝘂𝗺𝗲 𝘁𝗲𝗺𝗽𝗹𝗮𝘁𝗲

Modern ATS's use text-extraction to pull data from your resume – so simpler is better! You can find the one I personally used to land offers at Meta and Microsoft in the comments!

𝟮. 𝗞𝗲𝘆𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗱 𝗼𝗽𝘁𝗶𝗺𝗶𝘇𝗲 𝗯𝗮𝘀𝗲𝗱 𝗼𝗻 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗷𝗼𝗯 𝗱𝗲𝘀𝗰𝗿𝗶𝗽𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻

When reviewing resumes, recruiters often search for certain keywords. 

So if you don't have the right ones, your resume won't show up in the search. 

Here's a free tool that extracts the most important keywords to include based on the job you're applying to: https://lnkd.in/epQs7JQ8

𝟯. 𝗨𝘀𝗲 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗫𝗬𝗭 𝗳𝗼𝗿𝗺𝗮𝘁 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗿𝗲𝘀𝘂𝗺𝗲 𝗯𝘂𝗹𝗹𝗲𝘁 𝗽𝗼𝗶𝗻𝘁𝘀

This is the format that's recommended by recruiters at Google and a TON of large firms 

XYZ stands for: "Accomplished [X] as measured by [Y] by doing [Z]"

For example: 

"Increased social media impressions [X] by 20% [Y] by designing and executing new marketing strategies using Google Analytics and Hootsuite [Z]"

or 

"Reduced database processing time [X] by 30% [Y] by implementing query caching mechanisms using Redis [Z]"


Use this format for all of your resume bullets, and it’ll help you quantify your achievements.  

𝗜𝗳 𝘆𝗼𝘂'𝗿𝗲 𝗻𝗼𝘁 𝗳𝗼𝗹𝗹𝗼𝘄𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘁𝗵𝗲𝘀𝗲 𝘁𝗶𝗽𝘀, 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝘀 𝗶𝘀 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝘀𝗶𝗴𝗻 𝘁𝗼 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘁! :)

Write a motivational and empowering piece about the importance of recognizing one's worth in a professional setting, using the career progression of Elliott Hill at Nike as an example.

You've probably already seen Elliott Hill's story at Nike – he started as an intern and ended up as CEO. But there's a BIG part that you probably missed.

It's a heartwarming story of persistence and hard work paying off, right?

Equally as important is that Nike valued him from the start. 

On average, Elliott was promoted 𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘆 𝘁𝘄𝗼 𝘆𝗲𝗮𝗿𝘀. That’s not by accident. It’s because the company saw his potential and invested in it.

If you’re at a company that’s not promoting you, not recognizing your value, not giving you room to grow—𝘄𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗹𝗹 𝗱𝗼𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘁𝗵𝗲𝗿𝗲?

Loyalty to a company is fine, but loyalty to yourself comes first. You deserve to work where you’re appreciated and where your hard work leads to actual career growth.

If that’s not happening where you are, it’s time to move on. Don’t wait around hoping for things to change. Know your worth.

Write a post from the perspective of a full-time recruiter sharing a template and tips for job seekers on how to craft an effective cold email for job applications.

As a full-time recruiter, I’ve gotten hundreds of cold emails from job-seekers.

If you want a job from a cold email, 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗻𝗲𝗲𝗱 𝘁𝗼 𝗳𝗼𝗹𝗹𝗼𝘄 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝘀 𝘁𝗲𝗺𝗽𝗹𝗮𝘁𝗲:

I firmly believe the right cold email can land you an interview with any company.

But, there's a big difference between one that gets put in the 🗑️ and one that lands you the job.

Here's how to write a great one: 👇

"Hi [Recruiter's Name],

I noticed an open [Role] on [Company]’s website. I’m a [Job Title / School] with [Years of Experience], specializing in [Key Skills]. Recently, I worked on [Relevant Experience], which aligns directly with [Company’s Needs].

I've attached my resume and [Portfolio / LinkedIn], and I've applied to the job posting through the company website: [Hyperlinked Job Link].

Please let me know if there's anything I can do to expedite a conversation with yourself or someone on the hiring team.

Thanks,
[Your Name]"

Here's why this template works: 

↳ It's simple.

↳ It has a strong CTA.

↳ It immediately shows why you're the right fit. 

Cold emails can be a super easy way to stand out in the job market – if you're not sending them on top of filling out job applications, make sure to start!

-

Write a blog post about the frustrations of job searching and introduce a free browser plugin that simplifies the application process. Give credit to the creators of the plugin.

Job search is not fun. Answering the same questions on every application is annoying, especially in the current market, where over 80% of resumes end up in the trash before a human ever sees them, forcing applicants to mass-send resumes at a rate of 50+ per day.

Work authorization, gender, race, veteran status, disability - answering these questions over and over again felt to me like an enormous waste of effort that really benefits no one.

I got annoyed enough to almost start writing a Chrome plugin that would answer these questions once and for all. But then I realized that this pain is so obvious and widespread that surely some smart folks have already attempted to solve this nonsense. And sure enough, they had.

To everyone out there being victimized and brutalized by the bureaucracy machine - https://simplify.jobs/ is here to relieve you from your pain. It's an absolutely free and super easy-to-use browser plugin that will ask you those eye-irritating questions for the last time. Voila, now you can fill out application forms with just one click!

Huge thanks to Michael Yan and the Simplify team for making job searching a bit easier

Tell the story of how you successfully attracted the first thousand users to your startup using an unconventional marketing strategy related to a popular TV show.

I got my startup its first thousand users by handing out 25,000 Squid Game-themed business cards.

When I first launched Simplify in October of 2021, getting our first users was extremely tough.

We had a hard time convincing job seekers to sign up for what seemed like “just another job site” and we didn't have the money to run paid ads.

After watching Squid Game on Netflix, I had the idea of printing out business cards from the show with our branding on the back – and sliding them under doors on college campuses in the middle of the night. 

The vision was to capitalize on the virality of the show to get some eyeballs on our site.

My cofounders and I drove to over a dozen colleges to sneak into dorms and slide over 25,000 business cards under doors. 

It was time-consuming and our backs hurt for days – but it was exactly the type of jumpstart we needed to get our platform off the ground.

Today, Simplify has grown to help over half a million users discover and apply to 35 million jobs - and we’re still firm believers in scrappy growth strategies like this one! 🚀🚀

Write a text about an inspiring success story related to Juneteenth, highlighting the achievements of an influential figure in the Black community. The text should cover their personal journey, their impact on the community, and how they continue to give back. The figure should be Daymond John, the founder of the FUBU brand.

In honor of Juneteenth, I wanted to share one of my favorite success stories: 

In 1989, Daymond John was waiting tables at Red Lobster in Queens, New York. 

Frustrated by overpriced trendy hats, he decided to make his own – a brand called "FUBU", meaning “For Us, By Us”.

He started selling the hats locally, but investors didn’t believe in him enough to help him build the brand up. Eventually, John mortgaged his mother's house for $100,000 in startup capital. After struggling to make his idea work, things finally clicked when his neighbor, a rapper named LL Cool J, agreed to wear FUBU in a music video. 

That kickstarted the hype, which has now led to a $6 billion brand. 
Despite his success, I’m inspired by John’s commitment to give back to his community. 

Not only did FUBU play a major role in empowering the Black community and create dozens of jobs, he’s also leveraged his success in other ways to give back.    

In 2015, he launched the Black Entrepreneurs Day, a free global livestream giving guidance and grants to aspiring Black business owners. He's also an advocate for financial literacy in underserved communities.

In his "Success Formula" program, John has mentored thousands of young entrepreneurs, with a particular focus on nurturing talent in urban areas. He even frequently returns to his old neighborhood in Hollis, Queens, to speak at schools and community centers.

On Shark Tank, John is often the first to invest in Black-owned businesses and champions those founders. 

Truth is, he doesn’t need to do all this. 

But it’s inspiring that he’s choosing to. 

Choosing to become a beacon of possibility for Black youth, proving that with hustle and determination, anyone can achieve their dreams.

John’s dedication to uplifting his community reminds me that true success isn't just about personal wealth—it's also about creating opportunities for others. 

Happy Juneteenth everybody :)
—

This is a story of "breakfast funding" a Fortune 500 company: 

In 2008, Brian Chesky and his co-founders were in a bind. Their startup, Airbnb, was racking up debt, and investors weren't interested. "People won't let strangers in their homes," VCs scoffed.

Most founders would've scrambled for a bank loan or considered folding. Chesky thought, "Why not lean into our design skills?"

During the Obama-McCain presidential race, the trio had an unconventional idea: custom-designed cereal boxes. They created "Obama O's" and "Cap'n McCain's," filling each with cereal from local stores.

Chesky said, "We made 500 of each by hand—cutting, folding, and hot-gluing boxes." They weren't just selling cereal; they were selling artful, political collectibles.

The gamble paid off. At $40 per box, they sold out, netting $30,000. 

This wasn't just cash; it was runway to keep Airbnb alive. As Chesky puts it, "It literally saved our company."

That cereal money carried them to 2009, when they finally secured funding. From there, Airbnb exploded. Today, it's a $70+ billion company, with over 6 million listings worldwide.

Chesky's "cereal round" resonates deeply with me. It shows absolute relentlessness and the creativity to see it through 👏

—

Enjoy this?

Write a motivational story about how the concept of Netflix was born out of annoyance from a late fee, its journey from DVD rentals to becoming a streaming giant, and how this can inspire individuals to look at their daily annoyances as potential opportunities.

A $40 late fee led to Blockbuster's demise.

But it birthed a $230 billion streaming empire called Netflix.

This is a tale of turning annoyance into innovation: 

In 1997, Reed Hastings was annoyed. He'd returned Apollo 13 to Blockbuster six weeks late, incurring a hefty $40 fee. Most people would've grumbled, paid, and moved on.

Not Hastings. 

A successful software entrepreneur, he wondered: "Why can't renting movies be like a gym membership—a flat monthly fee, no late charges?" It wasn't just idle musing; he saw a business opportunity.

Hastings teamed up with Marc Randolph, and they launched Netflix—a DVD-by-mail service with no late fees. 

Critics scoffed. "DVDs? By mail? It'll never work." Even Blockbuster had a chance to buy Netflix for $50 million. 

They declined. Fast forward to 2007: 

Netflix, now a DVD rental giant, saw another shift coming: streaming. Despite DVD success, Hastings pivoted hard. Skeptics again said, "Streaming? Too slow, too new." 

But Hastings saw the future.

Today, Netflix has over 230 million subscribers, streams in 190+ countries, and is worth over $230 billion. 

Blockbuster? Filed for bankruptcy in 2010.

Hastings' journey resonates deeply with me.

It shows that our biggest frustrations—a late fee, a lost opportunity—can be signposts to the future. 

Now, I'm reevaluating my daily annoyances. 

Could one of them be my “Netflix” in disguise?

—

Tell the inspiring story of how Richard Montañez, a janitor at Frito-Lay, invented the popular Hot Cheetos snack and rose to become an executive at the company.

A janitor created Hot Cheetos. 

But Frito-Lay almost tossed his recipe in the trash.

This is how kitchen experimentation turned into a cultural phenomenon: 

Richard Montañez was mopping floors at Frito-Lay's California plant in 1976, making $4 an hour. Despite his position, he took the CEO's motivational words to heart: "Act like an owner."

One day, a machine broke down, leaving a batch of Cheetos without cheese. Montañez took some home, added chili powder—a staple in his Mexican-American community—and shared his creation with family. 

They loved it.

He then cold-called the CEO, pitching his "Hot Cheetos." Most executives would've dismissed a janitor's recipe, but this CEO heard him out.

In the boardroom, facing skeptical execs, Montañez presented his idea. 

His passion won them over – Frito-Lay launched Hot Cheetos, and it exploded in popularity.

Today, Hot Cheetos is a $1 billion brand, and a cultural icon. 

Montañez? He rose from janitor to executive.

Reflecting on Montañez's story, I'm struck by this: our biggest ideas might not come from our job titles, but from embracing our unique backgrounds and trying new things. 

~~~

Write a LinkedIn post announcing your career shift from being a biostatistician to a full-time recruiter, detailing your journey, key learnings, and inviting potential connections.

After 17 years in statistics and engineering, I've made a big career change.

Ten years into my job as a biostatistician, I realized that I had lost the joy of my work. 

What I did love was the process of building and managing great teams. But I still felt trapped at my job, and too old to job hop. 

In late 2019, I took a small jump and started freelance recruiting (part-time). During this time, I started contract work with Simplify, helping companies discover undertapped engineering talent.

With some encouragement from the founders (who were more than half my age), I'm proud to announce that I've moved into a full-time recruiter role.

This journey has taught me a few things:

- It's never too late to change your career path.
- Following your passion can lead to unexpected opportunities.
- The right support can make all the difference.
- Connecting people with their potential is incredibly fulfilling.

This is my first ever post on LinkedIn – and it's to tell you that it's never too late to pursue your passions.

If you're a job seeker looking for a career change, or an employer looking for top-tier talent, shoot me a connection request!

Write a LinkedIn post about your experience applying to internships, the lessons you learned about optimizing resumes for Automated Tracking Systems (ATS), and share a link to a blog where you provided tips on creating ATS-friendly resumes.

I applied to 150+ internships this past recruiting cycle.

Out of those applications, I landed ~15-20 interviews.

While a big part of job-searching comes down to the numbers game, I’ve learned there are ways to set yourself apart, even when cold-applying.

One of the keys is: optimizing your resume in the context of the ATS. 

The ATS refers to the automated tracking system recruiters use to help filter/manage candidates, which can play a big role in whether or not your application moves forward.

When I was struggling to land interviews, optimizing my resume’s format and getting advice from recruiters on my resume dramatically changed my interview success rate.

Recently, I spent hours reading 10+ articles on the topic and watching YouTube walkthroughs of how an ATS works in the context of job recruitment.

If you’re curious about what I learned, I just shared my top 5 tips to make an ATS resume in a blog with Simplify.

Feel free to check it out here: https://lnkd.in/gSAKqyz2

As someone who has faced an extensive job search process and finally landed a job, write a LinkedIn post sharing your experiences, the challenges you faced, and the strategies you used to overcome them, especially focusing on how technology helped you. Make sure to also include a hopeful note about sharing more about your journey and some relevant #hashtags to increase the reach of your post.

It took me THOUSANDS of job applications to land the job I have today. Not 100s. Thousands! I had to take up #contractwork in December and before that, I was unemployed for 6 months. #layoffs are tough, and the tech landscape is harsher than ever. As someone who's spent his entire professional career in #staffing, I want to start sharing bits of advice that helped me get the job I have today. 

My #1 tip is to use a Chrome extension to help you quickly fill out applications, as we all know hiring is a numbers game. I used Simplify pretty religiously as it's great for Greenhouse apps and helps you fly through the dreaded #workday job applications from hell (do better, Workday). 

In the same vein, you'll find yourself answering a lot of repetitive questions. Every time I answered an open-ended question, I added the question and my answer to a running document for easy copy-paste action. I was not about to explain why I love #marketing 3000 times. This can be a huge time-saver!

I'll be sharing more about my journey of returning to the workforce as I can - hopefully, it helps some people out there! 

#jobsearch #hiring #simplify #jobs #chromextension #jobapplicant #jobseeking #staffing #recruiting #hiring #timesaving #numbers #jobseekers #advice
Write a detailed guide on how you secured a last-minute internship as a Data Science Intern at Coupa Software in the Bay Area, including the steps you took and some hacks you found useful.

𝗧𝗿𝘆𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘁𝗼 𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗱 𝗮𝗻 𝗶𝗻𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗻𝘀𝗵𝗶𝗽 𝗹𝗮𝘀𝘁 𝗺𝗶𝗻𝘂𝘁𝗲? 𝗛𝗲𝗿𝗲’𝘀 𝗵𝗼𝘄 𝗜 𝗴𝗼𝘁 𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝗶𝗻 𝗠𝗮𝘆.
 
I didn’t start looking for/applying to internships until late April/May. I got an offer as a Data Science Intern at Coupa Software in the Bay Area on 5/22. Here were the steps that got me there:

💻 𝟭. 𝗨𝗽𝗱𝗮𝘁𝗲 & 𝘁𝗮𝗶𝗹𝗼𝗿 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗿𝗲𝘀𝘂𝗺𝗲 
Since it was later in the semester, I had gotten the chance to work on cool projects in & out of class. The hiring manager focused a lot on my projects & latest classes during my interview! 𝗛𝗮𝗰𝗸: 𝘂𝘀𝗲 𝗮 𝗸𝗲𝘆𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗱 𝘁𝗼𝗼𝗹 𝗹𝗶𝗸𝗲 Simplify 𝘁𝗼 𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗱 𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝘄𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗱𝘀 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗿𝗲𝘀𝘂𝗺𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝗺𝗶𝘀𝘀𝗶𝗻𝗴!
 
🚀 𝟮. 𝗠𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗮 𝗽𝗹𝗮𝗻 𝘁𝗼 𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗱 & 𝗮𝗽𝗽𝗹𝘆 (𝗮 𝗹𝗼𝘁) (𝗹𝗶𝘀𝘁: https://lnkd.in/gZhsFchV)
You should expect to submit more applications later in the cycle – I focused on smaller sized companies & startups and applied to newly posted positions. Filling out applications gets repetitive (I applied to over 100), so use Simplify!

Write a LinkedIn post about how you automated your job search using a browser extension called Simplify, detailing its features and providing suggestions for improvement.

How I automated my job search process and applied to 3x applications with the browser extension - Simplify 🚀 

☝🏼 One-Click Apply: helps you avoid the tedious and repetitive task of filling out application forms for each job 
📄 Resume Match: tells you how many keywords on your resume match with the job description
🤖 Application AI: personalized answers to job application questions

How I would improve Simplify: add a vertical stepper on the right side ✅✅❌✅ - After auto-fill, show users which sections are complete and direct them to the incomplete sections. Also note the optional sections

While Simplify helps you fill in most of the information, there are exceptions sometimes. As a user, I continue to double-check the info filled even after Simplify's auto-fill. This ensures all information is accurately filled, reducing the need for users to double-check every detail manually.

Super excited to be announcing our $3M fundraise led by Craft Ventures to build an AI copilot for job seekers!  🚀🚀

Ethan, Rushil, and I started Simplify in 2021 with a goal to help people navigate the (extremely painful) job search process and democratize access to personalized career support.

Super excited for what’s next! 🚀🚀

Write a blog post about the importance of understanding the recruiting season when seeking internships and new grad roles at Big Tech companies.

The thing I wish I knew sooner is: The importance of recruiting season.

Big Tech companies hire students a year in advance for internship and new grad roles

And 80-90% of roles open up during this time

So you definitely don't want to miss it...

This year I've noticed recruiting season still going strong through December

But not nearly at the same volume as other seasons

If you're still on the search, keep pushing because new roles are going live each day

And If you're just starting out, then make sure you're well prepared for next year!

Write a social media post about your experiences and observations a month after your job was eliminated. Include details about the challenges you've faced, the strategies you've used, and a call to action for recruiters and others who might be able to offer guidance. Also, give a shoutout to a product or service that has made the job search process easier for you.

✋ Life Update – Update(d) ✋

It's been almost a month since my role was eliminated. Here are some updates from a month in review as well as some requests from you ➡️ all:

1️⃣ - The job market is tough. Uniqueness to stand out is important. Having 'strong connections' is paramount to get your foot inside the door. Otherwise, you are simply a number of many applicants that may never get seen.

2️⃣ - Lots of automation. I have received a few denials thus far with no human interaction. I admire the companies that actually have an individual that replies, however, when you ask that individual for specific feedback, my response rate from those is 0%. What does that mean? Does it mean it's automated as well, or, am I missing something here?

3️⃣ - Tailoring is key, right? Well, let's discuss that. I have tailored my resume to each of the companies I have applied to. Meaning, I have ensured that my resume properly aligns to what the role is looking for. I still get the rejection notice that they are pursuing candidates that align better with the role. Hmm, strange.

4️⃣ - Uniqueness: I have tried LinkedIn premium messaging, customized emails, videos, and mailed hand-written notes with no response.

Any #recruiters out there willing to have a conversation with me to give me some guidance and feedback? Thanks in advance to all that comment to this post and share ideas and feedback with me. I welcome and can appreciate any and all guidance here during these challenging times. 

Also, hats off to the team over at Simplify, their product helps make keeping track of the application process simple.

#opentowork #jobsearch #salesjobs #softwarejobs

Discuss the stereotypes and challenges faced by Asian Americans in Corporate America and how they can overcome these hurdles. Include your personal insights and experiences as a child of Asian immigrants. Also, mention your latest essay on the subject and provide a link for interested readers to subscribe and share.

Asians are seen in Corporate America as workhorses that get the job done, but not racehorses, who ultimately will take you to the promised land. This stereotype of being hard-working perfectionists, unwilling to take big risks, stems from the immigrant scarcity mindset. 

Growing up the child of Asian immigrants can be both a blessing and a curse. We are raised with a hard work ethic and a focus on excellence, but also with a scarcity mindset and fear of failure. Although Asian Americans are the least likely to be promoted to executive ranks because of the bamboo ceiling, we must also take responsibility for the ways we hold ourselves small. Despite what we were raised to believe, hard work and strong performance are not enough to succeed. This is why we are often seen as workhorses, and not racehorses in the workplace. No one invests in their workhorses, because there is no future upside for them. But racehorses are nurtured and well-cared for, because they can yield great rewards. 

A scarcity mindset believes that there are finite resources and is focused on what you don’t have. An abundance mindset believes that you can grow the pie for everyone instead of believing everything is a zero-sum game. When you are constantly in self-preservation and survival mode, it is hard to see the bigger picture. You are always playing it safe and afraid to take risks or bet on yourself, because you are fixated on the cost and what you might lose. You also refuse to help others, because you are afraid that there won’t be enough for yourself. A scarcity mindset is always playing defense. But you can only lose or at best tie a game by only playing defense. You can only win by going on the offensive and putting points on the board. 

You have to be willing to take risks and that means making mistakes and ultimately failing sometimes. Many immigrants from Asia come from countries where entrance exams determine your future. Every mistake you make is costly. When you are raised to believe that anything less than 100% is unacceptable, you are programmed to fear taking risks and failing. In America, you don’t need to be 100% certain to be confident. Guessing and being wrong is okay. You learn from your mistakes and failures and you become more resilient because you recover from them. You don’t need to be perfect to be successful. We were conservatively raised to color within the lines, so as not to stand out. No one gets noticed for coloring in the lines. No one gets a promotion for doing the status quo. Taking risks by being unconventional and thinking outside the box is what gets recognized. Remember that you belong in the rooms you are in, so start acting like it.

I wrote about all of this and how we can overcome these hurdles, in my latest essay. Please subscribe for more content like this and share if it resonates with you!

Write a short article about the differences in job searching habits between Millennials, Gen Z, and older generations, and discuss how the platform "Simplify" is addressing these differences and improving job search results. Use statistics to back up your claims and conclude with a positive note about the future of job searching. Include relevant hashtags at the end.

Millennials and Gen Z are switching jobs every 2.8 years on average – nearly twice as often as older generations.

When surveyed, millennials & Gen Z tended to be more mission-driven and compensation sensitive (as they should be!) than previous generations. 

The traditional job search process of spending hours on job boards hunting for a position with the right qualifications, salary, benefits, and company mission isn't working for these younger generations.

On Simplify, we ran an experiment where candidates are only shown roles fitting their minimum requirements and the mission-statement for companies they apply to.

We've found that candidates are nearly 20% more likely to apply to a job they found on Simplify when compared to other hiring platforms.

We're excited to be helping people find more meaningful work that gets them paid fairly – and it's about time!

Write a post where you, as the founder of a tech internship repository started with Pitt CSC, announce the live list of Summer 2024 tech internships. In the post, mention your collaboration with a company called Simplify to improve the resource. Make sure to include the enhancements like doubling the number of internships, quicker job posting, and an improved contribution process. End the post with a thank you note and excitement for Simplify's future plans.

Summer 2024 tech internships list is live! 

Three years ago, Pitt CSC and I started the internship repository in hopes of creating a resource that Pitt students could use to find and apply to tech internships. Since then, it's been crazy to see what started as a pandemic idea grow into something used by millions of students worldwide. 

This year, I’m pumped to announce that we’ll be working with Simplify to take this resource to the next level. Thanks to Simplify’s help, the repo will now have:

📈 Nearly twice as many internships as before
🚀 New job postings added within hours of posting
⚡ A faster and easier contribution process

HUGE thank you to everyone who made the past 3 years possible. I can’t wait to see what Simplify does next. Hail to Pitt always!

I didn’t start looking for/applying to internships until late April/May. I got an offer as a Data Science Intern at Coupa Software in the Bay Area on 5/22. Here were the steps that got me there:

💻 𝟭. 𝗨𝗽𝗱𝗮𝘁𝗲 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗿𝗲𝘀𝘂𝗺𝗲 (𝘁𝗲𝗺𝗽𝗹𝗮𝘁𝗲: https://lnkd.in/gN-8Begy)
Since it was later in the semester, I had gotten the chance to work on cool projects in & out of class. The hiring manager focused a lot on my projects & latest classes during my interview!
 
🚀 𝟮. 𝗠𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗮 𝗽𝗹𝗮𝗻 𝘁𝗼 𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗱 & 𝗮𝗽𝗽𝗹𝘆 (𝗮 𝗹𝗼𝘁) (𝗹𝗶𝘀𝘁: https://lnkd.in/gJPnDtAs)
You should expect to submit more applications later in the cycle – I focused on smaller sized companies & startups and applied to newly posted positions. Filling out applications gets repetitive (I applied to over 100), so use Simplify!
 
📝 𝟯. 𝗨𝘀𝗲 𝗮 𝘀𝗽𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗱𝘀𝗵𝗲𝗲𝘁 𝘁𝗼 𝘁𝗿𝗮𝗰𝗸 𝗮𝗽𝗽𝗹𝗶𝗰𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀 & 𝗳𝗼𝗹𝗹𝗼𝘄-𝘂𝗽
I kept track of all my sent applications and followed up if I didn’t hear back (but don’t spam recruiters!). Companies often schedule interviews with shorter notices later in the cycle & my interview was scheduled in <a week – so be prepared for fast turnaround!

I'm happy to share a list of companies that are still hiring for summer interns & other advice – 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗲𝗺𝗮𝗶𝗹 ⬇️ (𝗲𝗱𝘂 𝗲𝗺𝗮𝗶𝗹𝘀 𝗽𝗿𝗲𝗳𝗲𝗿𝗿𝗲𝗱) 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗜’𝗹𝗹 𝘀𝗲𝗻𝗱 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗸!

𝗜𝘁’𝘀 𝗻𝗼𝘁 𝘁𝗼𝗼 𝗹𝗮𝘁𝗲 𝘁𝗼 𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗱 𝗮𝗻 𝗶𝗻𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗻𝘀𝗵𝗶𝗽, 𝗵𝗲𝗿𝗲’𝘀 𝗵𝗼𝘄 𝗜 𝗴𝗼𝘁 𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝗶𝗻 𝗠𝗮𝘆 𝗺𝘆 𝗳𝗿𝗲𝘀𝗵𝗺𝗮𝗻 𝘆𝗲𝗮𝗿:
 
I didn’t start looking for/applying to internships until late April/May. I got an offer as a Data Science Intern at Coupa Software in the Bay Area on 5/22. Here was the game plan that got me there:

💻 𝟭. 𝗨𝗽𝗱𝗮𝘁𝗲 𝗺𝘆 𝗿𝗲𝘀𝘂𝗺𝗲 (𝘁𝗲𝗺𝗽𝗹𝗮𝘁𝗲: https://lnkd.in/g-nkYf_n)
Since it was later in the semester, I had gotten the chance to work on cool projects in & out of class. The hiring manager focused a lot on my projects & latest classes during my interview!
 
🚀 𝟮. 𝗠𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗮 𝗽𝗹𝗮𝗻 𝘁𝗼 𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗱 & 𝗮𝗽𝗽𝗹𝘆 (𝗮 𝗹𝗼𝘁) (𝗹𝗶𝘀𝘁: https://lnkd.in/gT9AkHXR)
You should expect to submit more applications later in the cycle – I focused on smaller sized companies & startups and applied to newly posted positions. Filling out applications gets repetitive (I applied to more than >100), but grind it out!
 
📝 𝟯. 𝗨𝘀𝗲 𝗮 𝘀𝗽𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗱𝘀𝗵𝗲𝗲𝘁 𝘁𝗼 𝘁𝗿𝗮𝗰𝗸 𝗮𝗽𝗽𝗹𝗶𝗰𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀 & 𝗳𝗼𝗹𝗹𝗼𝘄-𝘂𝗽
I kept track of all my sent applications and followed up if I didn’t hear back (don’t spam). Companies often schedule interviews with shorter notices later in the cycle & my interview was scheduled in <a week – so be prepared for fast turnaround!

I'm happy to share more resources on companies that are still hiring & where to look – 𝙙𝙧𝙤𝙥 𝙖 𝙘𝙤𝙢𝙢𝙚𝙣𝙩 ⬇️ 𝙬𝙞𝙩𝙝 𝙮𝙤𝙪𝙧 𝙚𝙢𝙖𝙞𝙡 𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝙄 '𝙡𝙡 𝙛𝙤𝙡𝙡𝙤𝙬 𝙪𝙥!

I spent the last few weeks looking for gap-year internship & co-op opportunities for college students in hopes of avoiding a year of Zoom University. 

I was able to find 100+ internships over fall/winter/spring across fields like software, design, finance, business, legal, & more and compiled the links to these opportunities into a table. I’m happy to share with anyone that needs!

I also made a platform that’s like a “common application” for jobs, so you only have to fill out one application to apply to all 100 jobs (re-typing stuff is annoying)!

Write a TLDR-style LinkedIn post about a common app platform for internships, specifically supporting students with canceled opportunities due to COVID.

TLDR: We’ve created a “common application for internships” & are giving early access to students whose internships have been cancelled due to COVID-19. Sign up at www.simplify.jobs or drop your email below to be notified about opportunities!

Students! A couple friends and I have been working on Simplify for some time now, with the purpose of making internship-finding less stressful & more transparent for everybody. 

We’ve developed a common application & compiled 500+ jobs that you can apply to in just 1-click (auto-filled from your common app). We’re hoping this makes the internship process less tedious & stressful for all. :)

We currently have limited space (we just started beta tests last month!), so we’ll be prioritizing students with cancelled internships. However, we encourage all to sign up to stay notified about our official launch! 

Plus, we give you the option of adding your resume to our book that will be sent to a growing list of 50+ companies! 

Let’s support each other through these hardships. Stay home and stay safe! :)
